displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no? Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him? Doctor: Sure. I’m a too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I’m an ah aggressive guy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Um you’re a young guy. You don’t want to look back. Or if it was me, Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like- Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything.

Family Member: APS. Patient: She came here actually for one of the world experts on APS. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Which is a blood disorder. Clotting. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: I thought I would mention it ‘cuz I think for her – Doctor: I don’t know enough about that. I’d have to read up about that, but I don’t think it relates. Family Member: For her, it was a really easy fix. Doctor: That’s not a gene on this panel that they did for you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They do more common cancer genes. Family Member: Oh, I see.

Patient: …if, if it’s anywhere, if it’s, if it’s the same people that did the port if it’s people that as are as competent as the people that did the port, I have no problem with it at all. Doctor: Yeah. They do it all day long which is terrific. Patient: Because it was not, I mean it wss - it was a not, it was a total non-event. In and out, it was a total non-event. Doctor: Yeah. I agree. That’s that’s wonderful. Okay okay, sit tight here. I’m gonna have M____ come in. Patient: Alright. Doctor: She’s gonna harass you anyways. And then afterwards if we have other questions we’ll we’ll chit-chat some more. Patient: I would appreciate it if you would have your nutrition people take a look. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: ‘Cause you have all the latest data. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I mean I can go, I can go back to J___ - Dr. G____ and say hey, but them I’m gonna have to… Doctor: No no no. a look at it. Sure. Patient: I’m gonna have to, you know? I’m -

Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general. Doctor: Ehhhh -- Well it’s – uh. The immunotherapy’s targeted to the immune system, but it’s not targeted to your cancer. Again, it, too, is like chemotherapy, praying and hoping that it’s gonna attack your cancer. Patient: Uh-huh. Okay. Doctor: It definitely has less side effects than chemotherapy. It just has more risk because if it attacks you, then you can get into trouble faster. Patient: My hair will fall out again? Doctor: Nope. (Pause) Patient: Okay will it get curlier? Doctor: It got curlier because the old chemotherapy’s outta your system. Patient: Yeah. (Pause5sec) Family Member: Well, so, if I was your dad, what would you do? Let him have to decide? Doctor: Yeah. I, um, I don’t know – I’ve never made a decision for ya. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue is sort of your sense of what you do to your children, brother, what you want to do. You’re physically well enough. You, you know, if you can think about those things, I think a clinical trial makes a lot of sense.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I might need pictures if we can’t your catheter is out. So what’s the problem there? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So most of that really is just plumbing. Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: And so those are the cells that over time, as I said over an average of three to five years end up coming back, or returning and that’s what’s called - Family Member: Despite the hormone therapy. Doctor: Despite the hormone therapy. Family Member: So you can’t like change it, modify it, up it, lower it or whatever? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s been tried; even the addition of chemotherapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yet it prolongs the recurrence, but it still doesn’t prevent the recurrence or prevent it recurring. Healthcare Professional: But then there’s therapies that happen. Doctor: Right. That’s one of the last options Healthcare Professional: Yeah, yeah, there are other therapies for when that happens.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You are. Okay. No that’s critical information that I need to know (laughs) Family Member 2: He doesn’t like the trips. Doctor: I know, know. Patient: Yeah, that’s the thing. Family Member 2: It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s you know, now it’s only like every three weeks so… Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. Patient: It’s not quite that. It’s not so bad. Doctor: It’s much less so. Family Member: And there’s no affiliation obviously in Toledo that… Doctor: No. Not – well especially for these studies. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We are under such strict regulations that we can’t even do it in our own satellite in F____.

Healthcare Professional: Sorry, excuse me. Doctor: So um…just want to go over what's going on and sort of your scan results. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me ask first what your questions are. And then I can give you some thoughts. Patient: My question would be what are your thoughts about it? I mean, when you and I talked, we were kind of like, well, let's take the scans and see what comes up. We didn't necessarily think anything would because it's so small the numbers that we're reading right now. Doctor: Yeah, I still believe that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility.

Patient: Hm, I did not know that. Doctor: Yes and it’s one drug called Taxotere and it’s given through the IV so usually either arm… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …once over one hour every three weeks. Patient: Hm, okay. Doctor: Okay? We do have a study coming up doing that, plus vitamin C high dose. Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true.

Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh. Doctor: The key is you’re still – you know it’s still shrinking. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Until I get you – you could get five more, but if you beat me by getting your PSA to zero, then I’ll stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: How’s that for a challenge? Family Member: So if it comes back today and it’s zero?

Patient: Okay. Okay. So, just Doctor: Okay. You need the oxycodone and the walker. Patient: And the, uh, Xanax. Doctor: What is the third script? Patient: My Xanax. That’s it here. So, I’ll need, need that, right. Doctor: Let me see when I gave you the Xanax last. (Pause) Patient: Oh, Oh, I’m, I take ‘em, uh, probably every other day. You know, when I feel, when I’m depressed, man. You know, when I, when I feel down. Doctor: Yeah. So, this one, they will change. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And give you a chemo and lab appointment for this day because today we are holding off. And, then, your next one will be October twenty-fifth. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: So, they’ll give you all of that.
